text: <@UJJFDTN8G> I’ve gotten pushback from other writers as well, and I know other editors have as well. This is an issue that goes beyond one person, and it’s more than reasonable to ask for insight from a group of experienced people. And, of course, I did take it up with her. She’s not receptive to editing and sees it as bullying. That’s why I’m coming to the group.

text: I think you need to iterate why you're providing so much feedback. Sounds like they're way off the brief each time or missing the TOV for the company? Maybe walk through the next post together instead of just sending back another round of edits?

elements.text: I think you need to iterate why you're providing so much feedback. Sounds like they're way off the brief each time or missing the TOV for the company? Maybe walk through the next post together instead of just sending back another round of edits?

text: Or if it's a serious issue, there might be something unclear in your guidelines etc. I'd review these too if it's a widespread issue. Finding the root cause is the key here.

elements.text: Or if it's a serious issue, there might be something unclear in your guidelines etc. I'd review these too if it's a widespread issue. Finding the root cause is the key here.

text: Thanks dude - I think I might be lacking compassion in my edits. Will keep trying

text: I don't think compassion is the way forward. Just clarity.

elements.text: I don't think compassion is the way forward. Just clarity.

text: As someone who has received a lot of critical feedback, I think the thing that makes some feedback “too much” is if it disregards certain circumstances like the fact that a piece needed to be written on a tight deadline (then some concessions have to be made in quality and the feedback should keep this in mind), or the fact that it’s someone’s first article at the company and they haven’t nailed the tone of voice yet. I think if you show that you understand why the work doesn’t measure up (yet) that that could be helpful to the receiver. That way there’s no need for them to be defensive.

elements.text: As someone who has received a lot of critical feedback, I think the thing that makes some feedback “too much” is if it disregards certain circumstances like the fact that a piece needed to be written on a tight deadline (then some concessions have to be made in quality and the feedback should keep this in mind), or the fact that it’s someone’s first article at the company and they haven’t nailed the tone of voice yet. text: My point is that if she think you're being too hard then she can't understand why so many changes are relevant. That's what I mean by clarity.

elements.text: My point is that if she think you're being too hard then she can't understand why so many changes are relevant. That's what I mean by clarity.

text: If you think you're being clear enough and she's just being defensive, maybe she's not the best person for the job. If it's a tech thing, get her to spend time with the relevant people to improve her tech knowledge before she writes anything else.

text: Agree with all the great insights in this thread. Someone who sees editing as bullying probably is in the wrong role as a writer-- *but* it’s good to self-reflect on your role in team communication too! One thing that I sometimes find challenging as an editor, and always found frustrating as a writer, is edits for personal preference (“I wouldn’t do it that way”) vs edits clearly grounded in clarity, brand guidelines, messaging/positioning, etc. Providing feedback on what actually needs to change and why can help there. Sometimes I even link to our style guide so we’re always working off the same context.

elements.text: Agree with all the great insights in this thread. Someone who sees editing as bullying probably is in the wrong role as a writer-- *but* it’s good to self-reflect on your role in team communication too! One thing that I sometimes find challenging as an editor, and always found frustrating as a writer, is edits for personal preference (“I wouldn’t do it that way”) vs edits clearly grounded in clarity, brand guidelines, messaging/positioning, etc. Providing feedback on what actually needs to change and why can help there. Sometimes I even link to our style guide so we’re always working off the same context.

text:
Yeah I have a lot of questions about their motivations as well, but let’s focus on you since you’re the one who’s here.

Giving any writer the benefit of the doubt, I do think trust needs to be built between the writer and editor. While it’s nice when it happens automatically, sometimes it doesn’t for all sorts of reasons. In my experience, executives are most resistant to editing because they trust their own voice above all else and just want you to take what’s in their head and put it down on paper as-is.

I agree with Alicia that “showing your work” for a while can help build that trust. Reference what you know to be true at your organization and use it as a coaching opportunity for your new writer.

It may also be worth walking through your edits and comments face to face in non-COVID times and over Zoom right now so you start to build that rapport and relationship. Eventually you can drop that, but it might help them swallow your suggestions a bit better than just quipping back with (IMHO super unprofessional) comments like that.

elements.text:

While it’s nice when it happens automatically, sometimes it doesn’t for all sorts of reasons. In my experience, executives are most resistant to editing because they trust their own voice above all else and just want you to take what’s in their head and put it down on paper as-is.

I agree with Alicia that “showing your work” for a while can help build that trust. Reference what you know to be true at your organization and use it as a coaching opportunity for your new writer.

It may also be worth walking through your edits and comments face to face in non-COVID times and over Zoom right now so you start to build that rapport and relationship. Eventually you can drop that, but it might help them swallow your suggestions a bit better than just quipping back with (IMHO super unprofessional) comments like that.

text: ^ 100% to going through feedback face-to-face. Usually if my edits are small comments, I won’t do that, but if I see a piece and think “oh yikes” or have a ton of comments, I set up 15 min to go through. If they are a freelancer or you’re working async, I’ve started to use Loom videos to share context back and forth--not quite the same as live but still adds a human touch and lets them see your tone!

elements.text: ^ 100% to going through feedback face-to-face. Usually if my edits are small comments, I won’t do that, but if I see a piece and think “oh yikes” or have a ton of comments, I set up 15 min to go through. If they are a freelancer or you’re working async, I’ve started to use Loom videos to share context back and forth--not quite the same as live but still adds a human touch and lets them see your tone!

text: It’s probably a sensitivity on the part of the writer and there’s no need for them to be rude to you. But I find editing works best when you pair it with praise. Add a sprinkling of positive comments to any work you edit. People are more likely to change their behaviour when they feel proud vs when they feel frustrated, or like they aren’t doing much of anything right (again, writers should appreciate a great editor - you’re just trying to make us better writers :blush:, but some people do have greater sensitivities than others). I’ve worked as an editor for a company for a while and one of the other editors sent quite an aggressive email out to writers, belittling their writing skills - I pushed back against it and told him he was being too aggressive towards the writers, there’s no reason to be aggressive in feedback. I’m sure you’re not, but good relationships are everything - clarity AND compassion are important and you can bring both to nearly everything you do to strengthen your relationships with people. Having said that, some people are just quite difficult and can’t accept minor criticisms.

elements.text: It’s probably a sensitivity on the part of the writer and there’s no need for them to be rude to you. But I find editing works best when you pair it with praise. Add a sprinkling of positive comments to any work you edit. People are more likely to change their behaviour when they feel proud vs when they feel frustrated, or like they aren’t doing much of anything right (again, writers should appreciate a great editor - you’re just trying to make us better writers

, but some people do have greater sensitivities than others). I’ve worked as an editor for a company for a while and one of the other editors sent quite an aggressive email out to writers, belittling their writing skills - I pushed back against it and told him he was being too aggressive towards the writers, there’s no reason to be aggressive in feedback. I’m sure you’re not, but good relationships are everything - clarity AND compassion are important and you can bring both to nearly everything you do to strengthen your relationships with people. Having said that, some people are just quite difficult and can’t accept minor criticisms.

text:
There’s lots of useful advice in this thread from more experienced editors than me already, so I want to offer some words of encouragement. As someone who’s had the experience of being edited by you <@UKAK6J1NY>, I think you did a great job with providing clear feedback and being compassionate enough to explain why the changes were needed.

Granted, this was a one-time experience, but while reading about your experience I thought you were being hard on yourself. As other people have mentioned here, sometimes people are more sensitive to feedback, especially when someone has just started a new job (if it’s a new hire) and takes this feedback as criticism of their skills overall. I think a 1-on-1 with her explaining that your reasoning for giving so much feedback and reiterating that you’re not criticizing her skills in general but trying to improve a particular piece of writing should be helpful. If that’s not though, I think the problem is with this particular employee,  not your editing style :shrug:

text: <@UKAK6J1NY> You should check out the <http://aceseditors.org|aceseditors.org> community! Professional editors are trained in the art of feedback. It’s also very likely that you are “correcting” things that are unnecessary—you’ll learn all this and more through the ACES chats and webinars!
